name: Anonymous
com:
The Elder Scrolls 3: Morrowind is a poorly designed game, particularly when it comes to its quest design. Despite its reputation as a groundbreaking and immersive open-world game, Morrowind is filled with repetitive and tedious quests that quickly become boring and uninteresting.

First and foremost, the game's main quest is uninspired and dull. Instead of offering a rich and engaging narrative, Morrowind's main quest is a generic and uninteresting series of fetch quests and errands that quickly become tedious and uninteresting. This makes it difficult to become invested in the game's story or its characters, and it undermines the game's otherwise impressive world-building and storytelling.

Additionally, the game's side quests are equally uninspired and repetitive. Most of the game's side quests are simple fetch quests or kill quests that require players to go to a specific location and either collect an item or defeat a certain number of enemies. This makes the game feel like a chore to play, and it quickly becomes tedious and uninteresting.

Furthermore, the game's quest rewards are often unbalanced and unsatisfying. Instead of providing meaningful and useful rewards for completing quests, Morrowind often offers small amounts of money or low-level equipment that is quickly outpaced by the player's progress. This makes the game's quests feel like a waste of time, and it undermines the game's otherwise impressive world-building and storytelling.

Overall, The Elder Scrolls 3: Morrowind is a poorly designed game that fails to deliver on its potential when it comes to quest design. Its uninspired and repetitive main and side quests, combined with its unsatisfying and unbalanced rewards, make it a game that is tedious and unenjoyable to play.

Are you on Normal or Legend? Because on Normal none of the team comp matters at all. You can clear the FMT with absolute trash, underleveled, and with no good gear.
On Legend you start seeing why a lot of stuff is bad. Clerk falls off very quickly in Legend and is only useful for Shadow Stitch and Essence of Telephone Nunchaku. For a female attacker you are far better off being in Matriarch for Noblesse Oblige (But it's risky and not guaranteed damage) or Dealer for Darts Airstrike.
With Zhao specifically Gangster is pretty awful outside of the ladder Essence and even that is weaker than Han or Eri doing anything. You will be dealing like 800-1400 damage with the spicy knife Essence to a single enemy which is a joke when you can have Han slamming down Shield Ruptures in Enforcer for 1800-2400 and usually twice within just one or two other party member's attacks, and even with the ladder it's like 1200ish to 1600ish. In Breaker you will fare far better because of the fire buff paired with the Essence hitting all enemies and also buffing your agility and attack if I remember right but some enemies don't take as much from fire damage compared to Han's electric, and when it comes to 1v1 Breaker doesn't really have anything.

name: Anonymous
com:
So there’s this kid Mike who rides the bus with me. Mike brings his Steam Deck in the bus with him everyday and has been totally upsessed with musou games like Dynasty Warriors. Well, someone suggested that he should finally play a true JRPG and they recommended Library of Ruina.

so for the past week Mike has been playing Library of Ruina. Some of the other gamers have been helping him along to understand the various systems. How to clash and deckbuild, how different keypages work, etc. But he just. Can’t. Get it. All I hear is whining and anger from the back of the bus. “Why is the card selection gui so bad?” “What do you mean clashing for emotion points is a key strategy? Kill the fucking enemy, that’s my strategy”. And so on.

well, yesterday all of a sudden I hear “OH MY GOD THIS GAME IS FUCKING BULLSHIT!!!!!!” I turn around and there’s Mike and he’s LITERALLY CRYING. Apparently his party got staggered by a mass-summation attack and he couldn’t play the E.G.O. page when he needed to.

some of the other kids tried to console him and explain to him that there is deep strategy involved in turnbase JRPGs like Ruina, and that they never lost an invitation. But he was having none of it. Then he goes “MY MOM IS GOING TO CALL PROJECT MOON AND TELL THEM TO STOP MAKING THESE SHITTY SADISTIC GAMES!!!!”

it occurred to me that lots of gamers are like Mike. Gamers nowadays don’t have the patience and intelligence required for deep turnbase gameplay like what Ruina has. And so developers are catering to their desires and moving away from turnbased combat.

enjoy Ruina my friends, because it’s the last of a dying breed.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>620693732
Angela, for the first time in the story, has a wish -- not a yearning inspired by unbidden emotion, but an intellectual wish she chooses herself: to stay friends with Roland, to forgive his betrayal, and to make amends over the sin of her tantrum by filling the city with light as Ayin intended. This is to complete the plan that made her suffer for an unthinkable amount of years; really, it makes no sense for her to do this, on a personal level. It's unimaginably humiliating, infuriating, and gut-wrenching for her to do this. But she chooses to anyway, because it's her wish.

Roland, likewise, swallows all the rage and hatred he has for Angela and the destruction she wrought on his life and others. It makes no sense, but he does it, because despite the apathy he has been playacting as having the entire game, he does, ultimately, have a wish of his own: to fix the City, and not be a cog in its machine of suffering. He forgives her, and sets about trying to fix the world.

The most impactful revelation in the game for me was the reveal that those who had been invited to the library were those who had resonated with the light the most. Logically, to get the light back, Angela needed to invite them over and take it from them. But what was it that made them resonate with the light? They had wishes and dreams. If we go back to the very first key page one ever gets in the game... (picrelated)

Even the Rats had dreams. It was, indeed, there all along. Like a mind-blast, I suddenly reflected on all the characters and their dreams. The robot that wanted to eat food (a clear parallel to Angela), the Yun fixer who wanted to live up to his mother, the cannibal chef that wanted to become one of the Big 8... All of them had dreams.

>>620693794
And, of course, all of these dreams conflicted with reality. The City is like an amalgalm of all the suffering of the modern world; a corporate hellscape where people are ground into dust by the spinning gears of capitalism. It's as bad and painful as it can be. How's a rat supposed to dream about getting into the Nest or a big syndicate when they're struggling just to eat? How's one supposed to think big when every day is painful, every day is cold, every day seems to reinforce that dreams never come true and it's foolish to have a dream?

It's this conflict between dreams and reality - the desire to reach the unreachable, and the crushing feeling of it being unreachable - that I feel drives this game. It's said that distortions are not commonplace throughout the city because most people have given up on their dreams and think only for themselves. They don't think of being a Star, they think about how to pay rent or eat. A lot of the people who tag along into the library (but not those invited) just wanted to get books and get rich. The distortions are those who feel immense conflict between their dreams and reality, then give in and choose reality. They choose to stop going for the unreachable, and instead completely grasp what's within reach.

Philip gives up on being strong and happy. Those feel unreachable. He embraces what he feels to be true: that he's weak and that seeing, hearing, or doing things only hurts him. He becomes wax, melting by the flame.
Yan gives up on on free will. It feels unreachable. He embraces... you get the point.

Angela, a machine, questions Xiao on why she is about to sacrifice herself for love; why she is about to do something entirely illogical that will likely lead her right into death. Why she is angry at the library when it was Lowell who went in on his own. Xiao says: (picrel)

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>620693847
Angela, at this moment, doesn't understand. Xiao is not operating on rationality or what feels "reachable" or what she "wants." She, despite everything, has the hope that she can succeed no matter what; she dreams of her life with Lowell, which even she doesn't fully understand. And Nothing will stop her.

The Earth tries to chain her. She feels guilt with those who followed her die; she feels fear when the battle seems unwinnable; she feels like she was foolish.

The voice in her head tempts her to give up. It tells her that it's selfish to die in a fight when others will miss her or be harmed by her loss. Well, it's hard to tell everything the voice says, since we can only infer it by second-hand. In the end, she rejects the voice, and obtains EGO. She apologizes for one thing: having let her emotions briefly control her.

This is a valuable scene because it's one of the few times we see a character manifest E.G.O. rather than distort. It's a case where they defy their emotions, they defy what feels "reachable" and "logical", and go beyond: Xiao maintains her hope and aims for the unreachable: getting Lowell back, no matter how many reasons there are not to, no matter how ridiculous it is.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>620693903
Ego is defined as: "the part of the mind that mediates between the conscious and the unconscious and is responsible for reality testing and a sense of personal identity." It is one's identity, not how they emotionally react to things, not how they logically think about things, but the totality of their being. To distort is to lose your EGO and be controlled purely by the id, one's innate instinctive impulses - in Philip's case, to avoid pain; in Yan's case, to relinquish control; in Xiao's case, to give up on the impossible and foolish quest to get Lowell back when she knows she can't win. To become EGO is to reject all of this and maintain your identity, to follow your dream nonetheless. For it's not that we believe in things like hope and dreams because they are true; they become true because we believe in them.

Everyone in Ruina has wishes and dreams. That's perhaps why I found myself liking all of them; they each have a light. Reality tries to knock them down a peg. It tries to make them give up. It makes one say, "this is this, that is that" to escape the pain that comes from chasing dreams and failing. The antagonists are those who give up on their dreams, who chase the instinctual pleasure of musical reveberations, to revel in the piano of the soul. The protagonists are those who, ultimately, do not distort. They're those who maintain a firm grip on their E.G.O. They're those who maintain hope and keep reaching for the unreachable. They're the ones that say, "this is that, and this is that." They're those who got sick of weighing profits all their life.

They're those who aim to become Stars in the Sky, guiding lights amid the darkness.

>>620689993
I disagree then. Berlin was better than all other Hitman maps imo other than Hokkaido. It certainly is the best mission in the trilogy and one of the best in the entire franchise. Beautiful atmosphere, nice music, nighttime (always a plus), many different ways to kill targets with choices in the targets too, and some nice easter eggs as well.
Chongqing is not as good as a mission and but it is atmosphere kino.
For me Dartmoor fell apart after a few playthroughs. The house is just...boring. And running all the way to the greenhouse and the garden is also not nice. Once you discover all secrets via the detective sub-story, it loses 90% of its charm. Ironically, Dubai for me improved a lot on replay because it is really nicely interconnected, has tonnes of interesting kills, and a beautiful map.
